Terminamos en buenos términos; le deseo lo mejor y espero que todos nuestros fans lo apoyen en su decisión. Porque, después de todo, si un tipo no quiere estar en la banda, los fans tienen que entender que esa persona ya no quiere tocar para ellos. Y soy de los que opinan que nuestros fans se merecen lo mejor de lo mejor de este grupo. Sin importar quien sea el que toque la guitarra. Cada vez que subo a un escenario, no importa si estoy enfermo o en perfecto estado, les doy lo mejor de mí, y creo que eso me diferencia de un montón de otros músicos. Cuando llegue al punto de no estar totalmente interesado en subir a escena, abandono esto; no sigo, de ningún modo. No me parece justo para los fans, a quienes les cuesta ganarse el dinero para ver un show que les vuele el cerebro. Desde ese punto de vista, Marty tomó la decisión correcta: si no te interesa hacer esto, andate a tu casa.

es.question: ¿Cómo fueron los primeros shows con Al Pitrelli?
es.answer: Muy buenos. Muchos fans se acercaban y gritaban "¡Marty, Marty, firmame esto!". O sea que... ni notaron la diferencia. Hay algunas cosas de Al que me agradan mucho y a pesar de que Al hace las partes de Marty a la perfección, a su vez se toma pequeñas atribuciones para personalizar lo que está tocando.

es.question: ¿Cómo describirías esas atribuciones?
es.answer: Al es un tipo muy apasionado para tocar la guitarra, al igual que Marty; sin embargo, son dos músicos muy distintos. Tendrías que verlo en el escenario para darte cuenta de lo que quiero decir. Cómo muestra su personalidad en un show, cómo usa el lenguaje corporal, cómo toca para el público. La forma en que se comporta en el escenario está más relacionada con el hard rock o el heavy metal, en comparación con lo que hacía Marty. La verdad es que está haciendo un trabajo fabuloso y sorprende a casi todo el mundo, lo cual es muy difícil. Estoy bastante seguro de que Al será nuestro nuevo guitarrista. Es la primera vez que lo digo públicamente.

es.question: Una deuda que Megadeth mantiene con sus fieles seguidores de Buenos Aires es el disco en vivo que Dave Mustaine se encargó de prometer en cada una de sus visitas.
es.answer: Parece una broma, pero juro que cada vez que vamos a Buenos Aires le digo a mi manager: «Vamos a hacerlo» y él me contesta: « Después lo hablamos». Primero estábamos listos para hacerlo con Nick Menza, baterista del grupo hasta 1996 y justo se fue. La pregunta era: ¿sacamos un disco en vivo con Jimmy DeGrasso tocando las canciones de Nick? Una vez que nos convencimos y estábamos listos para hacerlo, simplemente no sucedió. ¿Por qué? Porque no pudimos arreglar todo lo que hace falta para grabar un disco en vivo. Es un asunto bastante complicado grabarlo en la Argentina, porque requerimos el mejor equipo técnico del mercado y no es sencillo trasladarlo desde los Estados Unidos hasta Sudamérica. A la vez, nos cuesta convencer a los técnicos de que se pasen una o dos semanas en Buenos Aires y comprueben cómo el público se vuelve loco (lo dice en castellano) por Megadeth. Este año a lo mejor hubiera sido posible, pero esta vez lo que falló fue la gira. De todas maneras, ya se lo dije a mi manager: no importa lo que haya que hacer, quiero grabar en Buenos Aires. La última novedad fue que los japoneses querían grabar un disco en vivo, y yo les contesté que no me interesaba hacerlo en Japón. La propuesta fue que ellos viajaran a Buenos Aires para hacerlo. Habrá que conversarlo.

es.question: Lo que muchos no saben es que esa deuda imaginaria comenzó a pagarse con "I'll Be There For You" (Estaré allí por ti), una de las mejores canciones que integran Risk, el último álbum del grupo.
es.answer: Fue hecha especialmente para tocar en la Argentina. Es un tema dedicado a los fans. Ellos estuvieron ahí por mí, y ahora es tiempo de que sea yo el que les diga: «Aquí estoy para ustedes». Repito que, para mí, la Argentina es el mejor lugar para tocar. Pueden buscar entrevistas de cualquier medio, que siempre digo lo mismo, inclusive en Chile, lo cual es peligroso para mi persona! (risas).

es.question: Lo que esos mismos fans desconocen es que Megadeth sigue con vida gracias a ellos, y que esa canción funciona como un final feliz de una historia que hasta este momento era inimaginable y que por primera vez el líder del grupo se atreve a contar:
es.answer: La segunda vez que fuimos a Buenos Aires, en 1995, yo estaba pasando por un momento terrible de mi vida por mis problemas con las drogas y el alcohol. En esa ocasión, el show que dimos en el Monsters of Rock, el festival que cerraba Alice Cooper, era la fecha final de nuestra gira. Cuando nos alejábamos del estadio en la camioneta, mi mente no paraba de pensar que se terminaba todo. Mi estado era tan deplorable que tenía ganas de parar, de que Megadeth tuviera un punto final. Encima, la relación interna de la banda no era la mejor y yo vivía peleándome con mi manager. Cuando llegué a mi casa, me puse a recordar el show; decidí que había estado tan bueno que no podía dejar que ese fuera el final. Y no lo fue. Medité al respecto, cambié de opinión, seguí con el grupo, dejé las drogas y el alcohol, y estoy sobrio desde ese entonces.

es.question: ¿Mantuviste en secreto aquella primera decisión de frenar?
es.answer: Hasta cierto punto. Creo que la banda algo se imaginaba, porque hablamos bastante al respecto. El problema con mi antiguo manager, que cometió muchos errores, acentuaba mi locura. El resto del grupo trataba de consolarme; me decían: "Calmate, tal vez sea un problema personal", y yo les contestaba: "Nada de problemas personales, él no hace su puto trabajo". Con el tiempo me dieron la razón, y esta persona renunció.

es.question: Mientras a principios de los 90 Megadeth y Metallica significaban la vanguardia de la música pesada, hoy están lejos de marcar nuevos caminos. La posta ha pasado a manos de Korn o Limp Bizkit.
es.answer: Cuando recuerdo los años en que surgimos, me da un poco de nostalgia. Lo que es seguro es que se trataba de heavy metal sin vueltas. En los primeros años salíamos de gira con grupos como Alice Cooper o Dio y les volábamos la cabeza al público, a los asistentes y a los mismos músicos. No tengo ningún problema con los nuevos grupos pesados; de hecho, no creo que estén nada mal. Lo que sí noto es que muchísimas de esas bandas suenan absolutamente igual. Y me refiero a las mismas canciones, los mismos sonidos y los mismos comportamientos en el escenario. En el campo estrictamente metálico, las cosas son totalmente diferentes: podrás decir que todos tienen el pelo largo y usan jeans gastados, pero si ves a Slayer y a Testament te vas a dar cuenta de que son muy distintos. Lo mismo sucede con Metallica y Megadeth. Ahora hay muchas bandas que suenan como Limp Bizkit o Korn... Si no sos un gran músico, al menos intenta ser original.

es.question: Casado en Hawai hace nueve años, Mustaine tiene dos hijos: Justis y Elektra. Su papel de padre fue otro de los motivos fundamentales para que el músico ordenara su vida: decidió adoptar un carácter tranquilo y amable, y sepultar aquel personaje irascible y endemoniado que le dio (mala) fama durante sus primeros días como personaje público. En el pasado, una entrevista con Dave era una ruleta rusa en la que el tiro podía salir para cualquier lado, y sus propios rencores asomaban en cada respuesta. Hoy, Mustaine deja que la pólvora se encienda únicamente en sus shows, y fuera del escenario aprendió a controlar sus demonios internos.
es.answer: Fue un aprendizaje en el que colaboraron tanto mi familia como mis fans. Sin embargo, todavía noto que muchos se me acercan con una demagogia que no me agrada demasiado. Me dicen: "Perdón, Dave, pero mi disco favorito es Rust In Peace" y les digo que no tienen por qué disculparse. Ellos piensan que sí, porque ya sacamos cuatro discos después de Rust In Peace, pero en realidad no me molesta. Con mis hijos pasa algo similar. No los juzgo por cómo se vistan o por lo que sientan. Me increpan diciendo: "No me gusta esto o lo otro", y no es algo acerca de lo que cual tenga que opinar; son decisiones de ellos. Cuando nos cruzamos con nuevos fans, me dicen: "Hola, Dave, Metallica es una mierda", y no hace falta que me digan eso para que los quiera. Honestamente, el comentario me irrita porque, además, Metallica me gusta.
es.note: La pregunta sobre el cambio de carácter está implícita en la declaración.

es.question: ¿Qué sucedería si tu hijo te dijera que prefiere a los Backstreet Boys antes que cualquier grupo heavy metal?
es.answer: Una vez le pregunté a mi hijo si le gustaban los Backstreet Boys y me dijo que no; eso me hizo muy feliz (risas). Pero si le gustaran Britney Spears o Christina Aguilera no me molestaría tanto, ¡porque al menos son algo agradable para ver..!

en.question: Everything was well organized for a tour through the main countries of South America, but some changes in governments caused closures in the stadiums where we were going to perform and the subsequent cancellation of the shows. That happened in Mexico City, in Monterrey and in some cities of Brazil. The final result was that the entire tour was canceled. Now, the possibilities of going to South America would only appear at the end of the year. I would have loved to play in Buenos Aires, because of how it makes me feel, but by the end of March the equipment is in Japan and moving it to Argentina costs thousands of dollars. This is a business and decisions like that cannot be made for many people to lose money. It's not fair.
en.answer: Everything was well organized for a tour through the main countries of South America, but some changes in governments caused closures in the stadiums where we were going to perform and the subsequent cancellation of the shows. That happened in Mexico City, in Monterrey and in some cities of Brazil. The final result was that the entire tour was canceled. Now, the possibilities of going to South America would only appear at the end of the year. I would have loved to play in Buenos Aires, because of how it makes me feel, but by the end of March the equipment is in Japan and moving it to Argentina costs thousands of dollars. This is a business and decisions like that cannot be made for many people to lose money. It's not fair.
en.note: Answer given as an explanation for the tour cancellation.

en.question: Far from taking advantage of the tour cancellation as a break, Megadeth decided to dedicate themselves to the pre-production of a future album. -We have just started writing the music and have not finished any particular song -Mustaine confesses-, but we are working on about nine or ten. Some are super heavy, like from the time of Rust in Peace and Countdown to Extinction, and others more melodic, like on Risk and Cryptic Writings. We all take care of the composition, including Al Pitrelli.
en.answer: We have just started writing the music and have not finished any particular song, but we are working on about nine or ten. Some are super heavy, like from the time of Rust in Peace and Countdown to Extinction, and others more melodic, like on Risk and Cryptic Writings. We all take care of the composition, including Al Pitrelli.
en.note: The question about the new music is implied in the statement.

en.question: After ten fruitful years, guitarist Marty Friedman left his position "to pursue other musical interests," according to an official statement on January 10. The immediate solution was Pitrelli. Faced with the first question about the definitiveness of the choice, Mustaine is decisive:
en.answer: When we have decided whether the replacement is temporary or not, we will release an official statement to the press letting it be known. Under current circumstances, what we are trying to do is make the transition as painless as possible. We supported Marty in his decision, and what we wanted was for the guitarist who took his place to be able to interpret his parts in the same way and satisfy the fans first, before ourselves.

en.question: How did you take his decision [Marty Friedman's]?
en.answer: Ten years is a long time and I regret not knowing him completely; I would have liked to get to know him much better during the time we were together. He made the decision that he thought was correct and, although I don't agree with him, he has my full support. I think that's what being friends is about: letting the other person do what they think is convenient, even if you think the opposite. Sometimes it turns out for the good; other times, not. The fact that Marty has taken this path to satisfy his new musical concerns seems fine to me, because he will be able to do whatever he wants; now, if that is so that his future works fulfill him in the same way that Megadeth's music satisfied him at some point, I'm not so sure that it will. The happiness he once had in this group seems to me to be an incomparable feeling. However, he wanted to make a change...

en.question: Did you sense his decision before he officially communicated it to you?
en.answer: Yes, I knew something was going on. There are times when you have to let people go where they prefer, and it may seem wrong to you. In my opinion, in this case he is very wrong, but I can't do anything but let him go. There is something very concrete, and that is that Marty was not happy in Megadeth. When I noticed it, I openly asked him if he no longer liked being in the group, if he didn't like touring or... if he didn't like being with me! And he answered that I was wrong regarding the relationship between the two of us, but that I had been right about the first two options. We ended on good terms; I wish him the best and I hope all our fans support him in his decision. Because, after all, if a guy doesn't want to be in the band, the fans have to understand that that person no longer wants to play for them. And I am one of those who believe that our fans deserve the best of the best from this group. Regardless of who plays the guitar. Every time I go on stage, no matter if I'm sick or in perfect condition, I give them my best, and I think that sets me apart from a lot of other musicians. When I get to the point of not being totally interested in going on stage, I quit this; I don't continue, by any means. It doesn't seem fair to the fans, who have a hard time earning the money to see a brain-blowing show. From that point of view, Marty made the right decision: if you're not interested in doing this, go home.

en.question: How were the first shows with Al Pitrelli?
en.answer: Very good. Many fans came up and yelled "Marty, Marty, sign this for me!". That is to say... they didn't even notice the difference. There are some things about Al that I really like and even though Al does Marty's parts perfectly, he also takes small liberties to personalize what he is playing.

en.question: How would you describe those attributes?
en.answer: Al is a very passionate guy about playing guitar, just like Marty; however, they are two very different musicians. You would have to see him on stage to realize what I mean. How he shows his personality in a show, how he uses body language, how he plays for the audience. The way he behaves on stage is more related to hard rock or heavy metal, compared to what Marty did. The truth is that he is doing a fabulous job and surprises almost everyone, which is very difficult. I'm pretty sure Al will be our new guitarist. It's the first time I've said it publicly.

en.question: A debt that Megadeth maintains with its loyal followers in Buenos Aires is the live album that Dave Mustaine promised on each of his visits.
en.answer: It seems like a joke, but I swear that every time we go to Buenos Aires I tell my manager: «Let's do it» and he answers: «We'll talk about it later». First we were ready to do it with Nick Menza, drummer of the group until 1996 and he just left. The question was: do we release a live album with Jimmy DeGrasso playing Nick's songs? Once we convinced ourselves and were ready to do it, it just didn't happen. Why? Because we couldn't arrange everything that is necessary to record a live album. It is quite complicated to record it in Argentina, because we require the best technical equipment on the market and it is not easy to transport it from the United States to South America. At the same time, it is difficult for us to convince the technicians to spend a week or two in Buenos Aires and see how the public goes crazy (he says it in Spanish) for Megadeth. This year it might have been possible, but this time what failed was the tour. Anyway, I already told my manager: no matter what needs to be done, I want to record in Buenos Aires. The latest news was that the Japanese wanted to record a live album, and I told them that I was not interested in doing it in Japan. The proposal was that they travel to Buenos Aires to do it. We'll have to talk about it.

en.question: What many don't know is that this imaginary debt began to be paid with "I'll Be There For You", one of the best songs on Risk, the group's latest album.
en.answer: It was made especially to play in Argentina. It is a song dedicated to the fans. They were there for me, and now it's time for me to tell them: «I'm here for you». I repeat that, for me, Argentina is the best place to play. You can look for interviews from any medium, I always say the same thing, even in Chile, which is dangerous for me! (laughs).

en.question: What those same fans don't know is that Megadeth is still alive thanks to them, and that that song works as a happy ending to a story that until now was unimaginable and that for the first time the group's leader dares to tell:
en.answer: The second time we went to Buenos Aires, in 1995, I was going through a terrible time in my life because of my drug and alcohol problems. On that occasion, the show we gave at the Monsters of Rock, the festival that Alice Cooper closed, was the final date of our tour. As we drove away from the stadium in the van, my mind wouldn't stop thinking that everything was ending. My condition was so deplorable that I wanted to stop, for Megadeth to come to an end. On top of that, the internal relationship of the band was not the best and I was constantly fighting with my manager. When I got home, I started remembering the show; I decided that it had been so good that I couldn't let that be the end. And it wasn't. I meditated on it, changed my mind, continued with the group, quit drugs and alcohol, and I've been sober ever since.

en.question: Did you keep that first decision to stop a secret?
en.answer: To some extent. I think the band guessed something, because we talked about it a lot. The problem with my old manager, who made many mistakes, accentuated my madness. The rest of the group tried to comfort me; they told me: "Calm down, maybe it's a personal problem", and I answered: "No personal problems, he doesn't do his fucking job". Over time they proved me right, and this person resigned.

en.question: While in the early 90s Megadeth and Metallica meant the vanguard of heavy music, today they are far from blazing new trails. The baton has been passed to Korn or Limp Bizkit.
en.answer: When I remember the years when we emerged, it gives me a little nostalgia. What is certain is that it was straightforward heavy metal. In the early years we toured with groups like Alice Cooper or Dio and we blew the minds of the audience, the attendees and the musicians themselves. I have no problem with the new heavy groups; in fact, I don't think they're bad at all. What I do notice is that many of those bands sound exactly the same. And I mean the same songs, the same sounds and the same behaviors on stage. In the strictly metal field, things are totally different: you can say that everyone has long hair and wears worn jeans, but if you see Slayer and Testament you will realize that they are very different. The same thing happens with Metallica and Megadeth. Now there are many bands that sound like Limp Bizkit or Korn... If you're not a great musician, at least try to be original.

en.question: Married in Hawaii nine years ago, Mustaine has two children: Justis and Elektra. His role as a father was another fundamental reason for the musician to put his life in order: he decided to adopt a calm and kind character, and bury that irascible and demonized character that gave him (bad) fame during his first days as a public figure. In the past, an interview with Dave was Russian roulette in which the shot could go anywhere, and his own grudges appeared in every answer. Today, Mustaine lets the powder ignite only in his shows, and off stage he learned to control his inner demons.
en.answer: It was a learning process in which both my family and my fans collaborated. However, I still notice that many approach me with a demagoguery that I don't like too much. They tell me: "Sorry, Dave, but my favorite album is Rust In Peace" and I tell them they don't have to apologize. They think they do, because we've already released four albums after Rust In Peace, but it doesn't really bother me. Something similar happens with my children. I don't judge them by how they dress or what they feel. They challenge me by saying: "I don't like this or that", and it's not something I have to comment on; they are their decisions. When we run into new fans, they tell me: "Hi, Dave, Metallica is shit", and they don't need to tell me that for me to like them. Honestly, the comment irritates me because, besides, I like Metallica.
en.note: The question about the change in character is implied in the statement.

en.question: What would happen if your son told you he preferred the Backstreet Boys over any heavy metal group?
en.answer: I once asked my son if he liked the Backstreet Boys and he said no; that made me very happy (laughs). But if he liked Britney Spears or Christina Aguilera it wouldn't bother me so much, because at least they're something nice to look at..!

title.es: ENTREVISTA A DAVE MUSTAINE: Después de la partida de Friedman
title.en: INTERVIEW WITH DAVE MUSTAINE: After Friedman's departure

summary.es: En esta entrevista, Dave Mustaine defiende firmemente a Megadeth como una banda a pesar de la salida de Marty Friedman, anunciando que Al Pitrelli acaba de firmar un contrato por diez discos con el nuevo sello Sanctuary, lo que prueba su permanencia. Elogia a Pitrelli por aprender "cada nota" de los solos anteriores y por tener una gran presencia escénica. Niega que Friedman se fuera por la dirección de *Risk*, afirmando que Marty fue parte de esa decisión (quería una canción lenta). Confirma que el nuevo material será más pesado, en línea con la tradición de Megadeth. Comenta sobre la gira con Mötley Crue, elogia a Slipknot sobre Limp Bizkit, y se posiciona en contra de Napster porque "roba" a las bandas, aunque entiende la necesidad de que los fans accedan a música. Finalmente, promete que Megadeth grabará y lanzará un álbum en vivo en Buenos Aires ahora que tienen un nuevo management y sello discográfico.
summary.en: In this interview, Dave Mustaine firmly defends Megadeth as a band despite Marty Friedman's departure, announcing that Al Pitrelli has just signed a ten-album contract with the new Sanctuary label, proving his permanence. He praises Pitrelli for learning "every note" of the previous solos and having great stage presence. He denies that Friedman left because of the direction of *Risk*, stating that Marty was part of that decision (he wanted a slow song). He confirms that the new material will be heavier, in line with Megadeth's tradition. He comments on the tour with Mötley Crue, praises Slipknot over Limp Bizkit, and takes a stand against Napster because it "steals" from bands, although he understands the need for fans to access music. Finally, he promises that Megadeth will record and release a live album in Buenos Aires now that they have new management and record label.

es.question: Después de la partida de Friedman, puede existir la sensación de que Megadeth ya no es una banda sino sólo tu proyecto solista.
es.answer: Si alguien le dijera eso a David Ellefson (el bajista de siempre), ¡él le patearía el culo! Megadeth siempre ha sido mi proyecto y también siempre ha sido una banda. Al Pitrelli toca a la perfección los solos de todos los guitarristas que pasaron por Megadeth, así que si cualquiera de nuestros fans de Buenos Aires nos escuchara ahora, estaría muy feliz porque sonamos como un puto concierto en vivo de Megadeth y no como una banda de bar.

es.question: Entonces, ¿sentías que sonaban como una banda de bar?
es.answer: No, pero sé que hay muchas bandas de bar que tocan covers de Megadeth y los guitarristas, cuando es tiempo de hacer mis solos o los de los otros guitarristas, simplemente se acercan lo más posible y se imaginan que eso es suficiente. Y no es suficiente: o lo hacés bien, o no lo hagas. Al y yo nos sentamos y aprendimos cada nota de cada solo de cada canción que tocamos. Además, él canta bien, tiene una gran presencia escénica y es muy amigable con los fans.

es.question: Cuando entró Pitrelli, no daba la sensación de que fuera un cambio permanente.
es.answer: Él acaba de firmar junto a Megadeth el contrato por diez discos con el sello Sanctuary. No sé, ¿es eso permanente? (se ríe a carcajadas).

es.question: Megadeth emitió un comunicado oficial en el que decía que Friedman se había ido porque tenía otros intereses musicales. ¿Podrías ser más específico?
es.answer: No sé, tendrías que preguntarle a Marty. Él quería tocar una música diferente de la de Megadeth.

es.question: ¿Tuvo algo que ver su partida con la nueva dirección musical de la banda en Risk?
es.answer: No, la nueva dirección en Risk fue parte de lo que él hizo. Yo quería que las canciones fueran más rápidas, pero cuando estábamos haciendo los arreglos, Marty dijo que necesitábamos una canción realmente lenta. Le contesté: Man, yo no puedo escribir lentos, esto me está matando. No sé, él ahora está feliz y nosotros también. No estoy enojado con Marty, pienso que es muy talentoso y que nos ayudó mucho a ser lo que somos.

es.question: Algunos fans se decepcionaron con esa nueva dirección musical de la banda, pero las nuevas canciones del compilado (Kill the King y Dread & the Fugitive Mind) suenan más parecidas a la tradición de Megadeth. ¿Eso es lo que se debe esperar en el futuro?
es.answer: Sí, a menos que... (se ríe). Iba a decir a menos que Marty vuelva a la banda (risas). No, creo que estamos haciendo lo que queremos.

es.question: ¿Cómo les fue en la gira con Mötley Crue?
es.answer: Fue muy divertida. Hacia el final del tour era como si nosotros fuéramos el número principal y le pateáramos el culo a Mötley Crue cada noche. Ellos tenían chicas bailando en ropa interior, bombas, fuego, papel picado y toda esa mierda sobre el escenario: era todo un show hollywoodense de rock stars. Y nosotros sólo salíamos con nuestros instrumentos, así que me sentía un poco incómodo. Pero hacia el final de la gira, pensé: ¿Sabés qué? Nosotros somos mejores, los fans nos quieren y nuestra música no se trata de que haya dos chicas con poca ropa bailando por ahí. No me importa un carajo si alguien toca después que nosotros. Al final del tour era bastante obvio de que fuimos mejor considerados cada noche. Y cuando terminábamos, nos subíamos a nuestro ómnibus para irnos y encontrábamos que había un tráfico increíble de gente que se iba del concierto mientras Mötley Crue todavía estaba sobre el escenario. Pero quisiera ser claro: Nikki (Sixx, bajista y fundador de Mötley Crue) es mi amigo y le deseo lo mejor con lo que haga. No sé si volverán a tener el nivel de popularidad que tuvieron, pero fue divertido verlos tocar algunas canciones que yo escuchaba mientras crecía.

es.question: ¿Qué pensás del ascenso de bandas como Slipknot o Limp Bizkit?
es.answer: No es la clase de música que escucho, pero son bastante excitantes. Para mí, Slipknot es mejor que Limp Bizkit, aunque éstos son más populares porque Fred Durst conoce el negocio musical y ha tomado ventaja de su influencia. Supongo que esto es un elogio para él. ¿Si yo escucho estas bandas de new metal? No. Sé quiénes son, pero la mayoría de los cantantes suenan igual, lo mismo que los bateristas, los guitarristas y los bajistas. Hay muchas bandas mejores que ésas.

es.question: ¿Qué opinás del episodio Napster?
es.answer: No me gusta. Ahora es muy diferente de cuando empezó. Quizás esté equivocado, pero creo que no es justo para una banda, que vive de hacer música y vender sus discos, que haya un sitio para que todo el mundo pueda sacar ese producto sin pagar. No creo que el tipo lo haya creado para robarle a las bandas sino para darle algo a los fans. Pero para darle algo a alguien, tenés que sacarle algo a otro. ¿Cómo te sentirías si yo entrara a tu casa y te robara tu puto televisor?

es.question: O sea que estás de acuerdo con la postura de Metallica.
es.answer: No, aunque entiendo lo que dice Lars. Él es muy rico y su lucha no es tanto para que un tipo que tiene millones de dólares tenga un millón más sino que se trata de que hay bandas que necesitan que les paguen por su música para poder seguir haciendo música. Si no, tendrán que hacer otra cosa para poder alimentar a sus familias. No creo que sea malo que la gente pueda bajar archivos MP3 de canciones que las bandas quieren poner gratis en Internet. En nuestra página web hemos puesto archivos MP3 gratis y videos para que la gente se los baje. O sea que no estoy en contra de la primera idea de Napster, pero es un hecho de que, aunque inventes algo bueno, hay gente que lo va a usar para mal. Es la naturaleza humana.

es.question: Ustedes grabaron un disco en vivo en Buenos Aires. ¿Eso va a salir publicado en algún momento?
es.answer: Nosotros no hemos grabado un disco en vivo en Buenos Aires porque nunca parecía ser el momento justo. Hemos esperado y esperado, pero ahora que cambiamos de management y de compañía discográfica, finalmente podremos hacerlo la próxima vez que vayamos. Ya no se trata de si pudiéramos, ahora se trata de cuándo.

es.question: Pero uno de sus conciertos sí fue grabado para ese disco que nunca salió.
es.answer: Nunca escuché esa grabación. La tiene la Rock & Pop. Pero la próxima vez que vayamos, finalmente haremos el disco en vivo.

en.question: After Friedman's departure, there may be the feeling that Megadeth is no longer a band but just your solo project.
en.answer: If someone said that to David Ellefson (the bassist forever), he'd kick their ass! Megadeth has always been my project and has also always been a band. Al Pitrelli plays the solos of all the guitarists who have been in Megadeth perfectly, so if any of our fans in Buenos Aires listened to us now, they would be very happy because we sound like a fucking Megadeth live concert and not like a bar band.

en.question: So, did you feel that you sounded like a bar band?
en.answer: No, but I know there are many bar bands that play Megadeth covers and the guitarists, when it's time to do my solos or those of the other guitarists, just get as close as possible and imagine that is enough. And it's not enough: either you do it well, or you don't do it. Al and I sat down and learned every note of every solo of every song we play. Plus, he sings well, has great stage presence, and is very friendly with the fans.

en.question: When Pitrelli joined, it didn't feel like a permanent change.
en.answer: He just signed the ten-album contract with the Sanctuary label along with Megadeth. I don't know, is that permanent? (laughs out loud).

en.question: Megadeth issued an official statement saying that Friedman had left because he had other musical interests. Could you be more specific?
en.answer: I don't know, you'd have to ask Marty. He wanted to play different music than Megadeth's.

en.question: Did his departure have anything to do with the band's new musical direction on Risk?
en.answer: No, the new direction on Risk was part of what he did. I wanted the songs to be faster, but when we were making the arrangements, Marty said we needed a really slow song. I replied: Man, I can't write slow ones, this is killing me. I don't know, he's happy now and so are we. I'm not mad at Marty, I think he's very talented and he helped us a lot to be who we are.

en.question: Some fans were disappointed with that new musical direction of the band, but the new songs on the compilation (Kill the King and Dread & the Fugitive Mind) sound more similar to Megadeth's tradition. Is that what should be expected in the future?
en.answer: Yes, unless... (laughs). I was going to say unless Marty returns to the band (laughs). No, I think we are doing what we want.

en.question: How did the tour with Mötley Crue go?
en.answer: It was very fun. Towards the end of the tour it was as if we were the headliner and kicked Mötley Crue's ass every night. They had girls dancing in underwear, bombs, fire, confetti, and all that shit on stage: it was a whole Hollywood rock star show. And we just came out with our instruments, so I felt a little uncomfortable. But towards the end of the tour, I thought: You know what? We are better, the fans love us, and our music is not about two barely dressed girls dancing around. I don't give a damn if someone plays after us. By the end of the tour it was quite obvious that we were better received every night. And when we finished, we got on our bus to leave and found that there was incredible traffic of people leaving the concert while Mötley Crue was still on stage. But I want to be clear: Nikki (Sixx, bassist and founder of Mötley Crue) is my friend and I wish him the best with whatever he does. I don't know if they will reach the level of popularity they once had again, but it was fun to see them play some songs that I listened to while growing up.

en.question: What do you think of the rise of bands like Slipknot or Limp Bizkit?
en.answer: It's not the kind of music I listen to, but they are quite exciting. For me, Slipknot is better than Limp Bizkit, although the latter are more popular because Fred Durst knows the music business and has taken advantage of his influence. I suppose this is a compliment to him. Do I listen to these new metal bands? No. I know who they are, but most of the singers sound the same, as do the drummers, guitarists, and bassists. There are many better bands than those.

en.question: What do you think of the Napster episode?
en.answer: I don't like it. Now it's very different from when it started. Maybe I'm wrong, but I think it's not fair for a band, that lives by making music and selling their records, that there is a site where everyone can take that product without paying. I don't think the guy created it to steal from the bands but to give something to the fans. But to give something to someone, you have to take something from another. How would you feel if I entered your house and stole your damn television?

en.question: So you agree with Metallica's stance.
en.answer: No, although I understand what Lars says. He is very rich and his fight is not so much for a guy who has millions of dollars to have one million more, but that there are bands that need to be paid for their music to be able to continue making music. Otherwise, they will have to do something else to feed their families. I don't think it's bad that people can download MP3 files of songs that the bands want to put on the Internet for free. On our website, we have put free MP3 files and videos for people to download. So I'm not against the first idea of Napster, but it is a fact that, even if you invent something good, there are people who will use it for evil. It's human nature.

en.question: You recorded a live album in Buenos Aires. Will that be released at some point?
en.answer: We haven't recorded a live album in Buenos Aires because it never seemed to be the right time. We have waited and waited, but now that we have changed management and record company, we will finally be able to do it the next time we go. It's no longer about if we could, now it's about when.

en.question: But one of your concerts was recorded for that album that never came out.
en.answer: I never heard that recording. Rock & Pop has it. But the next time we go, we will finally do the live album.

title.es: Dave Mustaine: "El Metal es Música para Marginados" | Entrevista 1992
title.en: Dave Mustaine: "Metal Works as Music for Outcasts" | Interview 1992

summary.es: Entrevista a Dave Mustaine en el programa The Arsenio Hall Show en 1992. Mustaine discute su famosa cita de que "el metal es música para marginados" [00:00:12], argumentando que la música heavy es un escape para aquellos que son menospreciados por su apariencia en Estados Unidos [00:01:06]. También relaciona el rechazo a los metaleros con problemas sociales como el desempleo y la sobrecualificación laboral, advirtiendo sobre las consecuencias de la exclusión social [00:01:49]. Al final, revela que el nombre de su hijo es Justice (Justicia) [00:02:28].
summary.en: Interview with Dave Mustaine on The Arsenio Hall Show in 1992. Mustaine discusses his famous quote that "metal works as music for outcasts" [00:00:12], arguing that heavy music is an escape for those who are looked down upon for their appearance in America [00:01:06]. He also relates the rejection of metalheads to social problems such as unemployment and job overqualification, warning about the consequences of social exclusion [00:01:49]. At the end, he reveals his son's name is Justice [00:02:28].

title.es: Entrevista a Dave Mustaine luego del show debut (1984)
title.en: Interview with Dave Mustaine after Debut Show (1984)

summary.es: Entrevista histórica con Dave Mustaine realizada inmediatamente después de los dos primeros shows de Megadeth (17 y 19 de febrero de 1984). Mustaine habla de la experiencia, mencionando que la segunda noche fue mucho más fluida que la primera [00:00:57]. Expresa un fuerte sentimiento de rivalidad con su antigua banda, Metallica, mencionando que la multitud coreó 'Kirk Hammett sucks' y 'Megadeth' [00:00:40], y declara: 'matamos a Metallica' en el Bay Area [00:06:07]. También menciona que Kerry King (de Slayer) tocó la guitarra en los shows, pero cuestiona su dedicación. Finalmente, detalla la lista de canciones de los primeros shows, incluyendo títulos como 'Burnt Offering', 'Love to Death' (sobre matar a su novia), 'The Next Victim', y el instrumental 'Quicksand' [00:03:37 - 00:05:34].
summary.en: Historic interview with Dave Mustaine conducted immediately after Megadeth's first two shows (February 17 and 19, 1984). Mustaine discusses the experience, noting that the second night was much smoother than the first [00:00:57]. He expresses a strong sense of rivalry with his former band, Metallica, mentioning the crowd chanted 'Kirk Hammett sucks' and 'Megadeth' [00:00:40], and declares: 'we killed Metallica' in the Bay Area [00:06:07]. He also mentions that Kerry King (of Slayer) played guitar at the shows but questions his dedication. Finally, he details the setlist from the first shows, including titles like 'Burnt Offering', 'Love to Death' (about killing his girlfriend), 'The Next Victim', and the instrumental 'Quicksand' [00:03:37 - 00:05:34].

title.es: Peace Sells... y la Destrucción del Mundo | Entrevista Megadeth 1986
title.en: Peace Sells... and the Destruction of the World | Megadeth Interview 1986

summary.es: Dos breves clips de entrevista con Megadeth para MTV en 1986 tras el lanzamiento de 'Peace Sells... but Who's Buying?'. David Ellefson describe el álbum como extremo, pero destacando que combina elementos de velocidad, partes lentas y melodía [00:00:12]. Dave Mustaine explica el significado del título, afirmando que es una crítica a la realidad: la paz no se puede comprar a pesar de los intentos de los líderes mundiales, y que la guerra está siempre latente, necesitando solo "un punk borracho" para desatarla [00:00:41].
summary.en: Two brief interview clips with Megadeth for MTV in 1986 following the release of 'Peace Sells... but Who's Buying?'. David Ellefson describes the album as extreme, but notes that it combines elements of speed, slow parts, and melody [00:00:12]. Dave Mustaine explains the title's meaning, asserting it is a criticism of reality: peace cannot be bought despite world leaders' attempts, and that war is always imminent, only taking "one drunk punk" to unleash it [00:00:41].

title.es: Entrevista con Megadeth | The Noite (17/11/17)
title.en: Interview with Megadeth | The Noite (11/17/17)

summary.es: Entrevista con Dave Mustaine y Kiko Loureiro, en la que hablan sobre la gira brasileña del álbum *Dystopia*. Kiko Loureiro menciona que Mustaine es un "tesoro nacional" en Brasil, pero bromea diciendo que es más difícil viajar con él porque lo lleva a lugares inapropiados [00:02:04]. Mustaine revela que Kiko fue contratado después de que el bajista le recordara que ya había tocado con él, lo que podría haberle ahorrado 20 audiciones [00:02:53]. Mustaine y Gentili bromean sobre el título del álbum *Dystopia* y la temática post-apocalíptica de los videos (inspirada en *Mad Max* de George Miller) [00:04:52]. Kiko Loureiro recuerda su experiencia de ser fan de Megadeth y tocar en Rock in Rio en 1991, y lo "surrealista" que es ahora tocar en el mismo escenario que Dave Mustaine [00:07:17]. Al final, Mustaine habla sobre su trabajo como actor de voz para una película de terror y presentan a Vic Rattlehead [00:13:06].
summary.en: Interview with Dave Mustaine and Kiko Loureiro, where they discuss the Brazilian tour for the album *Dystopia*. Kiko Loureiro mentions that Mustaine is a 'national treasure' in Brazil, but jokes that it's harder to travel with him because he takes him to inappropriate places [00:02:04]. Mustaine reveals that Kiko was hired after the bassist reminded him that he had already played with him, which could have saved him 20 auditions [00:02:53]. Mustaine and Gentili joke about the album title *Dystopia* and the post-apocalyptic theme of the videos (inspired by George Miller's *Mad Max*) [00:04:52]. Kiko Loureiro recalls his experience as a Megadeth fan and playing at Rock in Rio in 1991, and how 'surreal' it is now to play on the same stage as Dave Mustaine [00:07:17]. In the end, Mustaine talks about his voice acting work for a horror film and they introduce Vic Rattlehead [00:13:06].

title.es: Dave Mustaine y su Familia hablan de su Negocio de Vinos, Música, y Recorrido por su Hacienda en Tennessee
title.en: Megadeth’s Dave Mustaine and Family Talk Their Fine Wine Biz, Music, and Tour Their Tennessee Estate

summary.es: Entrevista con Dave Mustaine, su esposa Pam y su hija Electra, donde discuten el negocio familiar de vinos *House of Mustaine* [00:00:23]. Dave explica que el negocio comenzó tras actuar con la Sinfónica de San Diego en 2012 para unir a los fans de Megadeth y a los suscriptores de la sinfónica [00:03:05]. Electra, sommelier y vicepresidenta, detalla la filosofía de sus vinos italianos (de Le Marche), que son orgánicos y siguen métodos monásticos de un viñedo de 1,200 años [00:08:38]. El vino *Electra* es uno de los más raros del mundo [00:07:45]. Mustaine confirma que los vinos utilizan nombres de canciones de Megadeth (como 'Holy War' y 'Peace Sells') [00:15:28]. También habla sobre su salud (5 años en remisión de cáncer) [00:24:04] y bromea sobre el 'New Metal' y los guitarristas que no hacen solos [00:30:30]. Pam y Electra dan un recorrido por su finca de Tennessee, que mezcla diseños francés, inglés y ecuestre [00:33:00].
summary.en: Interview with Dave Mustaine, his wife Pam, and daughter Electra, discussing their family wine business, *House of Mustaine* [00:00:23]. Dave explains the business started after his performance with the San Diego Symphony in 2012 to unite Megadeth fans and symphony subscribers [00:03:05]. Electra, a sommelier and VP, details the philosophy of their organic Italian wines (from Le Marche), which follow monastic methods from a 1,200-year-old vineyard [00:08:38]. The wine *Electra* is one of the rarest in the world [00:07:45]. Mustaine confirms the wines use Megadeth song titles (such as 'Holy War' and 'Peace Sells') [00:15:28]. He also discusses his health (5 years in remission from cancer) [00:24:04] and jokes about 'New Metal' and guitarists who can't solo [00:30:30]. Pam and Electra give a tour of their Tennessee estate, which mixes French, English, and equestrian design elements [00:33:00].

title.es: Dave Mustaine: MEGADETH; el CANCER y su LEGADO (Gibson 2021)
title.en: Dave Mustaine: MEGADETH; The CANCER and His LEGACY (Gibson 2021)

summary.es: Documental de Gibson TV donde Dave Mustaine narra su vida y carrera. Detalla su infancia "anormal" [00:00:59], su salida de Metallica y la formación de Megadeth, cuyo nombre proviene de un panfleto [00:17:21]. Describe las dificultades de las giras iniciales y la experiencia de ser "productor" en el álbum *Killing Is My Business...* con un presupuesto de solo $4,000 [00:22:39]. Habla sobre hitos como el título de 'Peace Sells' [00:26:56] y el reclutamiento de Marty Friedman, cuya audición fue tan impresionante que "el cielo se abrió" [00:35:42]. En el ámbito personal, narra su sobredosis y experiencia cercana a la muerte [00:45:21], la parálisis del sábado por la noche que le impidió tocar [00:47:02], y su batalla contra el cáncer de garganta, donde un médico le dijo: "tienes el gran C" [00:51:03]. Finalmente, comparte su visión sobre su legado, con la esperanza de ser recordado como algo más que un "monstruo grande y aterrador" [00:58:48].
summary.en: Gibson TV documentary where Dave Mustaine narrates his life and career. He details his "abnormal" childhood [00:00:59], his departure from Metallica, and the formation of Megadeth, whose name came from a pamphlet [00:17:21]. He describes the difficulties of the initial tours and the experience of being a "producer" on the *Killing Is My Business...* album with a budget of only $4,000 [00:22:39]. He discusses milestones such as the title of 'Peace Sells' [00:26:56] and the recruitment of Marty Friedman, whose audition was so impressive that "the heavens opened" [00:35:42]. On a personal level, he recounts his overdose and near-death experience [00:45:21], the Saturday night palsy that left him unable to play [00:47:02], and his battle with throat cancer, where a doctor told him: "you have the big C" [00:51:03]. Finally, he shares his vision of his legacy, hoping to be remembered as more than just a "big scary monster" [00:58:48].

title.es: Dave Mustaine - Co-fundador y Líder de Megadeth | SRS #203
title.en: Dave Mustaine - Megadeth Co-Founder & Frontman | SRS #203

summary.es: Entrevista con Dave Mustaine, donde repasa su carrera y vida personal. Mustaine, co-fundador de Metallica y líder de Megadeth, revela que está trabajando en su 17º álbum [03:15:46]. Detalla su compromiso con las artes marciales, mencionando que está buscando su cuarto cinturón negro en BJJ (Jiu-Jitsu Brasileño) [00:05:43]. Sobre su infancia en la religión organizada, recuerda el trauma social de su hermana al ser expulsada [00:26:36] y las palizas que recibió con un cinturón de pistola [00:27:40]. Mustaine habla extensamente de su exitosa batalla contra el cáncer de garganta, explicando que grabó el álbum *The Sick, The Dying… And The Dead!* mientras estaba en tratamiento [03:18:09]. Confiesa que optó por no conocer los detalles del cáncer para evitar darle poder sobre él [03:17:24]. También menciona que su voz ha cambiado debido a la placa de fusión que tiene en el cuello tras una lesión con un quiropráctico en 2012 [03:18:42]. Finalmente, actualiza sobre el negocio familiar *House of Mustaine*, destacando sus vinos italianos sin sulfitos [03:16:34] y la construcción de un viñedo en Italia [03:16:20].
summary.en: Interview with Dave Mustaine, where he reviews his career and personal life. Mustaine, co-founder of Metallica and frontman of Megadeth, reveals that he is working on his 17th album [03:15:46]. He details his commitment to martial arts, mentioning that he is pursuing his fourth black belt in BJJ (Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu) [00:05:43]. Regarding his childhood in organized religion, he recalls the social trauma of his sister being disfellowshipped [00:26:36] and the spankings he received with a gun belt [00:27:40]. Mustaine talks extensively about his successful battle with throat cancer, explaining that he recorded the album *The Sick, The Dying… And The Dead!* while undergoing treatment [03:18:09]. He confesses that he chose not to know the cancer details to avoid giving it power over him [03:17:24]. He also mentions that his voice has changed due to the fusion plate in his neck following a chiropractor injury in 2012 [03:18:42]. Finally, he gives an update on the family business *House of Mustaine*, highlighting their sulfite-free Italian wines [03:16:34] and the construction of a vineyard in Italy [03:16:20].

title.es: Dave Mustaine entrevista a Slash: Rap, Saqueo y Anarquía en la Carretera
title.en: Dave Mustaine Interviews Slash: Rap, Pillage, and Anarchy on the Road

summary.es: Entrevista de 1989 entre Dave Mustaine y Slash, con Jeff Young presente en la introducción [00:00:01]. Mustaine le pregunta a Slash cuánta gente "destrozó" en su última gira [00:00:15]. Slash bromea sobre tener suficientes problemas legales, pero resume su ética de gira como: "Hice mi daño, todo el mundo sufrió por ello... sigo vivo" [00:00:28]. Los músicos bromean y están de acuerdo en que su modelo de vida es el de "rap, pillage and unemployed" (violación, pillaje y desempleo) [00:00:38]. La razón principal para seguir de gira, según Mustaine, es que "la cerveza es gratis y siempre puedes conseguir un sándwich" [00:00:43].
summary.en: A 1989 interview between Dave Mustaine and Slash, with Jeff Young present in the introduction [00:00:01]. Mustaine asks Slash how many people he "trashed" on his last tour [00:00:15]. Slash jokes about having enough legal hassles but summarizes his touring ethos as: "I did my damage, everybody suffered for it... I'm still alive" [00:00:28]. The musicians joke and agree that their life model is "rap, pillage and unemployed" [00:00:38]. The main reason for staying on tour, according to Mustaine, is that "the beer is free and you can always get a sandwich" [00:00:43].

title.es: MEGADETH - Hard n Heavy 1990. - Entrevista con Mustaine, Ellefson y Friedman
title.en: MEGADETH - Hard n Heavy 1990. - Interview with Mustaine, Ellefson, and Friedman

summary.es: Entrevista realizada por el programa francés *Hard n Heavy* a Megadeth, poco después del lanzamiento de *Rust in Peace* y con la alineación clásica con Marty Friedman y Nick Menza. Dave Mustaine aborda temas políticos y sociales. Discute la mentalidad de quienes están en el poder, afirmando que ven a la raza humana como "ovejas" y buscan "silenciosamente robarnos" como raza humana [00:15:30, cita de la fuente]. Habla sobre el respeto mutuo entre las bandas, incluso con aquellas con las que tuvieron rivalidades, como Slayer y Suicidal Tendencies [00:10:00, contexto]. El punto central de Mustaine es la gratitud hacia los fans, enfatizando que la audiencia es lo más importante en el mundo [00:18:15, cita de la fuente]. Señala que el dinero se convierte en una "barrera" entre el artista y los fans cuando se juega por él [00:19:30, cita de la fuente].
summary.en: Interview conducted by the French show *Hard n Heavy* with Megadeth, shortly after the release of *Rust in Peace* and featuring the classic lineup with Marty Friedman and Nick Menza. Dave Mustaine addresses political and social themes. He discusses the mentality of those in power, claiming they view the human race as "sheep" and enjoy "stealthifying us as a human race" [00:15:30, quote from source]. He talks about the mutual respect among bands, even those with whom they had rivalries, like Slayer and Suicidal Tendencies [00:10:00, context]. Mustaine's central point is his gratitude towards the fans, emphasizing that the audience is the most important thing in the world [00:18:15, quote from source]. He states that money becomes a "barrier" between the artist and the fans when they start playing for it [00:19:30, quote from source].

title.es: Metallica Entrevista COMPLETA 1983 (con Cliff Burton y Dave Mustaine)
title.en: Metallica FULL Interview 1983 (with Cliff Burton and Dave Mustaine)

summary.es: Entrevista de 1983 con la primera alineación de Metallica, incluyendo a Dave Mustaine y Cliff Burton [00:00:14]. La banda confirma que se formó en octubre de 1981 [00:00:26]. Entre sus principales influencias, mencionan a Angel Witch, Motörhead, Black Sabbath y Diamond Head [00:00:44]. La banda afirma que planea hacer de la música rock su carrera [00:01:02]. Cuando se les pregunta si su música involucra a Satanás, responden con ironía: "Satanás apesta" [00:01:13]. Confirman que planean entrar al estudio el 1 de mayo en Rochester, Nueva York, para grabar su álbum debut (el cual sería *Kill 'Em All*) [00:01:24]. Al comparar a las audiencias, afirman que las de San Francisco son "mucho mejores" y que el público de Los Ángeles "apesta" [00:01:40]. Su consejo para una banda nueva es: "Renuncia", "intenta ser diferente" [00:02:04] y "Metal up your ass" [00:02:18].
summary.en: 1983 interview with the early lineup of Metallica, including Dave Mustaine and Cliff Burton [00:00:14]. The band confirms they formed in October 1981 [00:00:26]. Among their main influences, they mention Angel Witch, Motörhead, Black Sabbath, and Diamond Head [00:00:44]. The band confirms they plan to make rock music their career [00:01:02]. When asked if their music involves Satan, they respond ironically: "Satan sucks" [00:01:13]. They confirm plans to enter the studio on May 1st in Rochester, New York, to cut their debut album (which would be *Kill 'Em All*) [00:01:24]. Comparing audiences, they assert that San Francisco's are "a lot better" and that Los Angeles "sucks" [00:01:40]. Their advice for a new band is: "Quit", "try and be different" [00:02:04], and "Metal up your ass" [00:02:18].

title.es: Testimonio Dave Mustaine - El lado oscuro y su conversión
title.en: Dave Mustaine Testimony - The dark side and his conversion

summary.es: Entrevista donde Dave Mustaine habla sobre su fe y experiencias con el ocultismo. Mustaine afirma que no tiene dudas sobre la existencia del diablo, cuya "mayor mentira" es haber convencido a la gente de que no existe. Describe al diablo como "muy hermoso", no como un "monstruo" con cola puntiaguda [00:00:13]. Menciona que no toda la música Heavy Metal está infundida con poder demoníaco, ya que hay bandas que "creen en Dios y lo glorifican", y que él y su banda rezan todas las noches antes de subir al escenario [00:00:57]. Mustaine explica que fue criado como Testigo de Jehová, pero se "rebeló" hacia la brujería porque odiaba salir a tocar puertas [00:01:53]. Relata dos experiencias como adolescente donde cree que los hechizos funcionaron: uno lanzado a un *bully* que resultó herido en un accidente de coche [00:02:06] y otro que resultó en que una chica fuera a su apartamento al día siguiente [00:02:20]. También describe haber hecho "pactos de sangre" en la adultez [00:02:58]. Mustaine establece una relación entre su alcoholismo y el satanismo, señalando que cada vez que practicaba algo satánico, había estado bebiendo [00:03:31]. Finalmente, afirma que es "más peligroso" ahora como cristiano que antes, porque está "armado con la verdad" [00:04:01].
summary.en: Interview where Dave Mustaine discusses his faith and experiences with the occult. Mustaine states he has no doubt about the devil's existence, whose "greatest lie" was convincing people he doesn't exist. He describes the devil as "very beautiful," not a "monster" with a pointy tail [00:00:13]. He mentions that not all Heavy Metal music is infused with demonic power, as there are bands that "believe in God and glorify him," and that he and his band pray every night before going on stage [00:00:57]. Mustaine explains that he was raised as a Jehovah's Witness but "revolted" into witchcraft because he hated going out knocking on people's doors [00:01:53]. He recounts two experiences as a teenager where he believes the hexes worked: one cast on a bully who was injured in a car accident [00:02:06] and another that resulted in a girl showing up at his apartment the next day [00:02:20]. He also describes making "blood pacts" in adulthood [00:02:58]. Mustaine establishes a relationship between his alcoholism and Satanism, noting that anytime he had been doing anything satanic, he had been drinking [00:03:31]. Finally, he asserts that he is "more dangerous" now as a Christian than he ever was before because he is "armed with the truth" [00:04:01].

title.es: Dave Mustaine - Entrevista con Riki Rachtman (MTV Headbangers Ball 1990)
title.en: Dave Mustaine - Interview with Riki Rachtman (MTV Headbangers Ball 1990)

summary.es: Entrevista corta de MTV, parte del programa *Headbangers Ball*, con Dave Mustaine, en la que se promociona el inminente lanzamiento del álbum *Rust in Peace* (1990). Mustaine anuncia que el álbum saldría a la venta esa misma semana [00:00:18]. Describe el álbum como un LP de 9 canciones, con más de 40 minutos de material y sin versiones (*covers*), siendo el álbum más largo de Megadeth hasta la fecha [00:00:39]. Destaca a los dos nuevos miembros: Marty Friedman en la guitarra y Nick Menza en la batería [00:00:46]. Mustaine afirma que, gracias a la nueva alineación, han recuperado su "fuego" y que las cosas les están yendo muy bien [00:00:51]. El video de su primer sencillo, 'Holy Wars... The Punishment Due', fue estrenado en MTV y ese mismo segmento estaba compitiendo en la sección *Ball Buster* del programa [00:01:00].
summary.en: Short MTV interview, part of the *Headbangers Ball* show, featuring Dave Mustaine promoting the imminent release of the *Rust in Peace* album (1990). Mustaine announces that the album would be shipped that week [00:00:18]. He describes the album as a 9-song LP, with over 40 minutes of material and no cover songs, making it Megadeth's longest album to date [00:00:39]. He highlights the two new members: Marty Friedman on guitar and Nick Menza on drums [00:00:46]. Mustaine states that, thanks to the new lineup, they have gotten their "fire back" and things are looking very good for them [00:00:51]. The video for their first single, 'Holy Wars... The Punishment Due', was world-premiered on MTV and was currently competing in the *Ball Buster* segment of the show [00:01:00].

title.es: Fox News | Dave Mustaine habla sobre cómo la pandemia impactó la composición de canciones para 'The Sick, The Dying... and The Dead!'
title.en: Fox News | Dave Mustaine talks how the pandemic impacted his songwriting for TSTDATD (June 24, 2023)

summary.es: Entrevista con Dave Mustaine en Fox News sobre el éxito del álbum *The Sick, The Dying... and The Dead!* (2022). Mustaine y la entrevistadora, Kennedy, recuerdan su encuentro cuando ella era VJ de MTV en 1994 [00:00:51]. Al ser consultado si la "locura del mundo" (incluida la pandemia) había sido buena para su composición, Mustaine dice que no lo pondría en ese contexto, pero intenta usar los temas que "todos enfrentamos" en sus letras [00:01:10]. Explica su enfoque lírico: no tiene "favoritismos de partidos políticos" [00:02:05] y se centra en "problemas que nos afectan a todos", ofreciendo la perspectiva de alguien que ha vivido solo desde los 15 años [00:02:08]. Su objetivo es presentar los "pros y contras" de un problema para que la gente se pregunte: "No quiero lo que Dave tiene, ¿pero quiero lo que yo tengo?" [00:01:32]. Mustaine revela que no sigue mucho las noticias de actualidad porque está muy ocupado, pero confía en que la gente "lo corregirá y seguiremos adelante" [00:03:09].
summary.en: Interview with Dave Mustaine on Fox News about the success of the album *The Sick, The Dying... and The Dead!* (2022). Mustaine and the interviewer, Kennedy, recall meeting when she was an MTV VJ in 1994 [00:00:51]. When asked if the "craziness of the world" (including the pandemic) had been good for his songwriting, Mustaine says he wouldn't put it in that context, but he tries to use issues that "we all deal with" in his lyrics [00:01:10]. He explains his lyrical approach: he has "no political party favoritism" [00:02:05] and focuses on "issues that affect all of us," offering the perspective of someone who has been living on his own since age 15 [00:02:08]. His goal is to present the "pros and cons" of an issue so people ask themselves: "I don't want what Dave has, but do I want what I have?" [00:01:32]. Mustaine reveals that he doesn't watch much current affairs because he is so busy, but he trusts that people will "correct it and we're going to move on" [00:03:09].

title.es: Lars Ulrich y Dave Mustaine Terapia Subtitulada en Español
title.en: Lars Ulrich and Dave Mustaine Therapy Subtitled in Spanish

summary.es: Clip del documental *Some Kind of Monster* que muestra una sesión de terapia entre Dave Mustaine y Lars Ulrich. Mustaine expresa el dolor de haber visto a todos decir que Kirk Hammett era un gran guitarrista y que él era un "perdedor" expulsado de Metallica, un sentimiento con el que ha lidiado por casi 20 años [00:00:02]. Se siente frustrado porque todo lo que Metallica toca "se convierte en oro" mientras que sus proyectos "siempre fracasan" [00:00:32]. Mustaine confronta a Ulrich por la falta de advertencia o "segunda oportunidad" antes de ser expulsado en 1983 [00:02:44], diciendo que vendió todo para unirse a ese sueño y luego terminó [00:03:21]. Reconoce que su despido fue justificable debido a su "enfermedad" (adicción) y por ser "peligroso" [00:02:22]. Ulrich admite sentir "algo de culpa" [00:01:16] y describe una "abrumadora tristeza y culpa" [00:05:45] por la forma en que Mustaine fue despedido, recordando que detrás de su fachada dura, Dave era una persona "realmente tierna" [00:05:57]. Mustaine dice que "daría cualquier cosa" porque en 1982 le hubieran dicho: "Oye Dave, necesitas ir a AA" [00:07:55].
summary.en: Clip from the *Some Kind of Monster* documentary showing a therapy session between Dave Mustaine and Lars Ulrich. Mustaine expresses the pain of watching everyone say Kirk Hammett was a great guitarist and that he was a "loser" kicked out of Metallica, a feeling he has dealt with for almost 20 years [00:00:02]. He is frustrated because everything Metallica touches "turns to gold" while his projects "always backfire" [00:00:32]. Mustaine confronts Ulrich about the lack of warning or a "second chance" before being fired in 1983 [00:02:44], saying he sold everything to join that dream and then it ended [00:03:21]. He concedes that his firing was justifiable due to his "disease" (addiction) and for being "dangerous" [00:02:22]. Ulrich admits feeling "some guilt" [00:01:16] and describes an "overwhelming sadness and guilt" [00:05:45] about how Mustaine was let go, recalling that behind his tough exterior, Dave was a "really tender person" [00:05:57]. Mustaine says he would "give anything" for a chance to have been told in 1982: "Hey Dave, you need to go to AA" [00:07:55].

title.es: Joe Rogan Experience #1861 - Dave Mustaine (Fundador de Megadeth)
title.en: Joe Rogan Experience #1861 - Dave Mustaine

summary.es:
Dave Mustaine se une a Joe Rogan para hablar sobre su carrera, su formación en artes marciales y su vida personal. Mustaine reflexiona sobre su "salvaje viaje" como miembro fundador de Metallica y líder de Megadeth [00:00:14]. Gran parte de la conversación se centra en su dedicación a las artes marciales, un interés que le dio mucho ánimo y lo ayudó a salir de problemas [00:02:39].

**Artes Marciales:**
* Detalla su entrenamiento bajo la leyenda Benny "The Jet" Urquidez, de quien recibió su primer cinturón negro [00:01:22].
* Cuenta historias asombrosas de la carrera de Benny, incluyendo una pelea brutal en Tailandia donde Benny pateó la frente de un oponente con una patada de espinilla repetidamente [00:03:26].
* Revela que tiene un cinturón negro en Taekwondo Anti-Clinton y un cinturón morado en Jiu Jitsu [00:11:23].
* Mustaine y Rogan discuten la historia de Benny's y sus hermanos, que supuestamente confrontaron a Frank Dux sobre el origen de la historia de *Bloodsport*, alegando que se basaba en las experiencias de Benny [00:06:13].

**Otros Temas:**
* Menciona la locura del negocio de la música, incluyendo el incidente donde un conductor de autobús dejó a toda una banda varada en la frontera canadiense por un DUI [00:31:03].
* Hablan de autos y su preferencia por los vehículos ingleses como Aston Martin y Range Rover [02:53:55].
* Mustaine da su opinión sobre los actores de James Bond, llamando a Daniel Craig el Bond/asesino más "creíble" [02:55:11].
summary.en:
Dave Mustaine joins Joe Rogan to discuss his career, martial arts background, and personal life. Mustaine reflects on his "wild ride" as a founding member of Metallica and the frontman of Megadeth [00:00:14]. A large part of the conversation focuses on his dedication to martial arts, an interest that gave him a lot of encouragement and helped him get out of trouble [00:02:39].

**Martial Arts:**
* He details his time training under the legendary Benny "The Jet" Urquidez, from whom he received his first black belt [00:01:22].
* He recounts amazing stories from Benny's career, including a brutal fight in Thailand where Benny repeatedly kicked an opponent's forehead with a shin kick [00:03:26].
* He confirms he holds a black belt in Anti-Clinton Taekwondo and a purple belt in Jiu Jitsu [00:11:23].
* Mustaine and Rogan discuss the story of Benny's brothers confronting Frank Dux over the origin of the *Bloodsport* story, claiming it was based on Benny's experiences [00:06:13].

**Other Topics:**
* He mentions the craziness of the music business, including an incident where a bus driver abandoned a band at the Canadian border due to a DUI [00:31:03].
* They discuss cars and his preference for English vehicles like Aston Martin and Range Rover [02:53:55].
* Mustaine gives his opinion on James Bond actors, calling Daniel Craig the most "believable" Bond/assassin [02:55:11].

title.es: Dave Mustaine quiere que el último show de Megadeth sea en el espacio
title.en: Dave Mustaine wants Megadeth's final show to be in outer space

summary.es: Dave Mustaine revela su ambición de que el concierto final de Megadeth se celebre en el espacio, posiblemente en la Luna, antes de finalizar su carrera con el decimoséptimo álbum de estudio y la gira de despedida. Mustaine citó como precedente a celebridades y empresarios como William Shatner y Richard Branson, y argumentó que los viajes espaciales comerciales están progresando más rápido de lo que la gente cree. Afirmó: "Vi que enviaron a un montón de celebridades al espacio y pensé: 'Bueno, si a ellos, ¿por qué no a mí?'". Mustaine estima que la gira de despedida de Megadeth podría durar entre tres y cinco años, tiempo en el que espera que la tecnología avance lo suficiente. También confirmó que su álbum final autotitulado incluirá una versión de 'Ride The Lightning' de Metallica.
summary.en: Dave Mustaine reveals his ambition for Megadeth's final concert to be held in outer space, possibly on the Moon, before ending their career with the upcoming 17th studio album and final world tour. He cited the precedent of celebrities and entrepreneurs like William Shatner and Richard Branson traveling to space, and argued that commercial space travel is progressing faster than people think. He stated: "I saw they sent up a bunch of celebrities into space and I thought 'Well, if them, why not me?!'". Mustaine estimates that Megadeth's final world tour could run for another three to five years, during which time he hopes technology will advance enough. He also confirmed that their final, self-titled album will include a cover of Metallica's 'Ride The Lightning'.

es.text:
El líder de Megadeth, Dave Mustaine, ha puesto el listón particularmente alto a la hora de establecer el escenario para su ideal show final con las leyendas del thrash metal. El carismático líder de la banda, que ha confirmado que su inminente decimoséptimo álbum de estudio y la gira mundial que lo acompaña serán su capítulo final, le dice a Metal Hammer que quiere que su último concierto sea en el espacio. ¡No, en serio!

"Espero que estemos tocando en el espacio", revela en una nueva entrevista exclusiva. "Creo que será un clímax realmente apropiado. Y no estoy hablando de hacerlo a un lado de un cometa de vómito. Un concierto en la Luna, un aterrizaje en luna llena, eso sería genial".

Refiriéndose a figuras como la superestrella del pop Katy Perry, la leyenda de Star Trek William Shatner y el multimillonario de Virgin Richard Branson, quienes han realizado viajes al espacio en los últimos años, MegaDave añade: "Vi que enviaron a un montón de celebridades al espacio y pensé: 'Bueno, si a ellos, ¿por qué no a mí?', ¿sabes? Solo estoy observando cómo progresa todo eso. Sé que Elon Musk y Richard Branson estaban trabajando en viajes interestelares. Creo que la gente viajará al espacio mucho antes de lo que crees".

Cuando Hammer le preguntó si estaba bromeando sobre la idea de tocar un concierto en el espacio exterior, Dave duplicó su convicción de que podría suceder algún día.

"La gente ya viaja a más de 40.000 pies de altitud, y cuando llegas a ese tipo de atmósfera, básicamente ya estás en el espacio", argumenta (aunque técnicamente la mayoría de los estudios espaciales coinciden en que el espacio exterior comienza más cerca de los 327.000 pies). "Así que creo que sucederá. La pregunta es, ¿la gente podrá habitar la luna?".

Basándose en este hilo de pensamiento en particular, Dave continúa: "Personalmente, nunca querría vivir en un planeta lejos del mundo en el que vivimos. La gente estaba hablando de un viaje a Marte, ¡pero todo lo que puedo imaginar es que alguien de repente diga: '¡Oh! Olvidé mi cepillo de dientes!' ¡Ese sería el vuelo más largo de la historia!'".

Las cosas tendrían que escalar bastante rápido para que Dave llegara al espacio incluso con su generosa estimación de que la gira mundial final de Megadeth podría durar otros tres o cinco años, pero han sucedido cosas más extrañas. Si Metallica puede tocar en la Antártida, ¿por qué Megadeth no puede tocar donde ninguna banda ha tocado antes?!

El álbum final de Megadeth, autotitulado, llegará en enero y incluirá una versión del clásico de Metallica 'Ride The Lightning'. Puedes pedir una variante exclusiva de vinilo de cobre y esmeralda del álbum a través de la tienda oficial de Metal Hammer.

en.text:
Megadeth leader Dave Mustaine has set a particularly high bar when it comes to setting the scene for his ideal final show with the thrash metal legends. The band's talismanic frontman, who has confirmed that their imminent seventeenth studio album and accompanying world tour will be their final chapter, tells Metal Hammer he wants his last concert to be in space. No, really!

"I hope we'll be playing up in space," he reveals in an exclusive new interview. "I think that will be a really fitting climax. And I'm not talking about on the side of a vomit comet. A gig on the Moon, a full moon landing, that would be cool."

Referring to the likes of pop superstar Kay Perry, Star Trek legend William Shatner and Virgin billionaire Richard Branson having all made trips into space in recent years, MegaDave adds: "I saw they sent up a bunch of celebrities into space and I thought 'Well, if them, why not me?', you know? I'm just watching how that all progresses. I know Elon Musk and Richard Branson were working on interstellar travel. I think people are going to be travelling to space a lot sooner than you think."

Asked by Hammer if he's joking about the idea of actually playing a gig in outer space, Dave doubles down on his conviction that it could happen one day.

"People already travel over 40,000 feet altitude, and when you get to that kind of atmosphere you're basically already in space," he argues (although technically most space studies agree that outer space begins at closer to 327,000 feet). "So I do think it's going to happen. The question is, are people going to be able to inhabit the moon?"

Building on this particular thread of thought, Dave continues: "Personally I'd never want to live on a planet away from the world we live in. People were talking about a trip to Mars, but all I can imagine is somebody suddenly going 'Oh! I forgot my toothbrush!' That would be the longest flight ever!'"

Things would have to escalate quite quickly for Dave to get to space even with his generous estimate that Megadeth's final world tour could go for another three-five years, but stranger things have happened. If Metallica can play Antarctica, why can't Megadeth play where no band has played before?!

Megadeth's final, self-titled full-length album will land this January, and will include a cover of Metallica classic Ride The Lightning. You can order an exclusive copper and emerald vinyl variant of the album via the official Metal Hammer store.
